title: 110_s2812
content: The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008, also known as the Act, includes provisions such as an increase in the types of originating sites and expanding the eligibility of practitioners to provide telehealth services. It aims to improve the process for updating the list of telehealth services. The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008 expands the types of facilities eligible for telehealth services, including skilled nursing facilities, renal dialysis facilities, and community mental health centers. The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008 expands telehealth services to various facilities, including skilled nursing facilities, renal dialysis facilities, and community mental health centers. Additionally, the act allows for telehealth services at any site with a telecommunications system without a facility fee for certain originating sites. The Medicare Telehealth Improvement Act of 2008 allows for telehealth services at any site with a telecommunications system without a facility fee for certain originating sites. The amendments made by this section will apply to services furnished 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act. Expansion of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services. Expansion of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services by amending Section 1834(m) of the Social Security Act to include physical therapists as practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services. Expansion of practitioners eligible to provide telehealth services by amending Section 1834(m) of the Social Security Act to include physical therapists, occupational therapists, speech-language pathologists, audiologists, certified providers, and other individuals or entities determined appropriate by the Secretary. The amendments made by subsection (a) shall apply to services furnished on or after the date that is 90 days after the date of enactment of this Act. SEC. 4. IMPROVEMENT OF PROCESS FOR UPDATING THE LIST OF TELEHEALTH SERVICES. The Telehealth Advisory Committee's recommendations must be considered by the Secretary when adding or removing services and HCPCS codes. If a recommendation is not implemented, the Secretary must provide a reason in the Federal Register. The Telehealth Advisory Committee is established to make recommendations to the Secretary on adding or removing services and HCPCS codes for authorized payment under the Social Security Act. If a recommendation is not implemented, the Secretary must provide a reason in the Federal Register. The Telehealth Advisory Committee, established to advise the Secretary on payment recommendations under the Social Security Act, consists of 7 members appointed by the Secretary, including five practicing physicians and two non-physician healthcare providers. The Telehealth Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary, must have members with prior experience in telemedicine or telehealth, preference given to those currently providing services, and a balance of specialties and geographic representation. The Advisory Committee, appointed by the Secretary, will have members with experience in telemedicine or telehealth, representing various specialties and regions. Members will serve for a specified term, meet twice a year, and not be subject to the Federal Advisory Committee Act. The Secretary will establish the Advisory Committee without being limited by the number of advisory committees allowed, as per the Advisory Committee Act.
